questions.question_text:
Multiple teams are sharing a tenancy in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI). You are asked to figure out an appropriate method to manage OCI costs.
Which is NOT a valid technique to accurately attribute costs to resources used by each team? (Choose the best answer.)

choices.C: Create an Identity and Access Management (IAM) group for each team. Create an OCI budget for each group to track spending.
choices.A: Create a Cost-Tracking tag. Apply this tag to all resources with team information. Use the OCI cost analysis tools to filter costs by tags.
choices.D: Define and use tags for resources used by each team. Analyze usage data from the OCI Usage Report which has detailed information about resources and tags.
choices.B: Create separate compartment for each team. Use the OCI cost analysis tools to filter costs by compartment.

discussion.content:
C
Budgets are set on cost-tracking tags or on compartments not by user groups

Selected Answer: C
C is correct

comments.content: The correct answer is C as the question asks which method is not valid. Applying cost-tracking tags to resources and then using the cost analysis tools is a valid method.

You set up a bastion host in your VCN to only allow your IP address (140.19.2.140) to establish SSH connections to your Compute Instances that are deployed in a private subnet. The Compute Instances have an attached Network Security Group with a Source Type: Network Security Group (NSG), Source NSG:
NSG-050504. To secure the bastion host, you added the following ingress rules to its Network Security Group:
//IMG//

However, after checking the bastion host logs, you discovered that there are IP addresses other than your own that can access your bastion host.
What is the root cause of this issue? (Choose the best answer.)

choices.A: The Security List allows access to all IP address which overrides the Network Security Group ingress rules.
choices.B: All compute instances associated with NSG-050504 are also able to connect to the bastion host.
choices.D: A netmask of /32 allows all IP address in the 140.19.2.0 network, other than your IP 140.19.2.140
choices.C: The port 22 provides unrestricted access to 140.19.2.140 and to other IP address.
